bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, February 20, 1909

div1.p: Gorgas describes the achievements of the Panama Canal Zone Sanitary Department.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, February 20, 1909

opener.dateline:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, CANAL ZONE
February 20, 1909;

div1.p:
Inclosed I send you copy of article written at the request
of the mosquito extermination Society of New York, I am not
bombarding you with these articles with any intention of
slowly sapping your health but merely to keep you in
touch with the position I am taking in these matters.

Dr. Reed gets of Wednesday. We have all been looking after
him so that he has come to think Panama a fine place.
We fear that if he haven't it in too rosy colors our salaries
may be cut down.

I think that we have the yellow fever scotched. The first
case since the sielt was reported this morning. On the
first of February, out-of a force of (8000) eight thousand
men, we had only 115 in hospital, pretty good for Panama,
We are rapidly making Panama a health resort. And
the Sanitary Department did it all. That has a familia,
ring, But, seriously, though Panama may look in
many things, we certainly have winter weather that
cannot be beaten, Cannot you come down mal-
mouth & hag me a little visit & see for yourself.
With Kindest-regards I remain's
